text: The conference took place in Liege on 26 and 27 April. At the event the Agency presented main findings from its second EU-wide minorities and discrimination survey, an overview of its work in the area of sport and arts, and future activities on these topics at the Fundamental Rights Forum on 25-27 September.

title: Equality data subgroup agrees guidance on improving data
text: The FRA-facilitated subgroup was set up under the High Level Group on Non Discrimination, Equality and Diversity chaired by the European Commission. It is preparing the guidelines for adoption by the High Level Group. The meeting took place in Brussels on 26 and 27 April in Brussels.

title: Strategic litigation to help end child labour
text: The meeting on 27 April in Brussels aimed at having an informal exchange of views on how strategic litigation can be used to tackle these violations and to create a network, operating in a child rights framework, to eradicate child labour. The meeting brought experts from the European Commission, UNICEF, the Council of Europe and specialised civil society organisations.  FRA highlighted the relevance and possible links to its Opinion on business and human rights, its forthcoming study on access to remedies for business-related human rights abuses, and its study on severe labour exploitation.

title: Help media speak out against injustice
text: “A free press is one of the hallmarks of a well-functioning and vibrant democracy. It holds a mirror to our society to tell it how it really is,” says FRA Director Michael O’Flaherty. “To keep power in check, Member States need to refrain from interfering with press freedoms. They need to ensure journalists can freely probe and challenge while exposing legitimate concerns.” A recent BBC poll found that most Europeans believe their countries has become more polarised than a decade ago; almost a half see their societies as less tolerant. This is partly being driven by populist rhetoric gaining traction in many places coupled with challenges to the rule of law and judicial systems. The media plays a vital role in informing people and exposing untruths, rights violations, injustice and abuses of power. It engages people in issues that society need to be aware of and empowers them to make informed decisions. It also holds politicians and governments accountable for their actions, keeping record of what was said and done before. However, Reporters Without Borders’ 2018 press freedom index points to worrying tendencies in Europe, traditionally a safer haven for journalists. Journalists are being threatened and attacked repeatedly for doing their job, as a 2016 FRA paper also noted. The horrific murders in Slovakia of the journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancee, Martina Kušnírová, in March this year and the investigative reporter, Daphne Caruana Galizia, in Malta in October 2017, were poignant testimonies of the extreme dangers journalists can face. They are also confronted with online intimidation. Female journalists are particularly on the receiving end of abusive comments and threats left by readers. This risks jeopardising balanced media coverage of such issues as refugee integration or anti-racist demonstrations. Media consolidation is also placing pressure on the work of the media. Journalists may face commercial influence over editorial content as more and more media outlets are in the hands of fewer owners. Such abuse and pressure risks undermining press freedom, freedom of information and freedom of expression. This calls for greater efforts to counter this challenges and protect the media. The European Commission’s recent whistleblower rules are an example of what can be done to help. Offering stronger guarantees to protect sources will relieve some of the pressure journalists face when exposing injustice and speaking freely to defend the many whose rights have been violated.

title: Visit of the office of Hungary’s Fundamental Rights Commissioner
text: The visit aimed at continuing and further strengthening cooperation between the Agency and the Hungarian NHRI. An extended exchange of information on respective areas of activities and priorities allowed for a fruitful exploration of potential areas of future cooperation.

title: Five priorities to guide FRA’s work
text: The priorities build on the findings from the Agency’s independent external evaluation that in 2017 surveyed FRA’s key partners and stakeholders. The evaluation underlined how stakeholders value the Agency’s high quality fundamental rights support, drawn from its expertise and the robust evidence it collects. Moving forward, the FRA strategic plan 2018-2022 identifies five priority areas that will guide the Agency’s work each year during this period. These include: Identifying trends: collecting and analysing comparable data; Contributing to better law making and implementation: providing independent advice; Supporting rights-compliant policy responses:  providing real-time assistance and expertise; Effectively promoting rights, values and freedoms; Strengthening cooperation with national and local fundamental rights actors: working with communities of support. In addition, the plan describes the Agency’s strategic objectives and core activities in each priority area. These include: the continued use of large-scale quantitative surveys alongside its comparative data analyses; the provision of assistance and expertise on fundamental rights issues to EU bodies and national authorities; continued on-the-ground support to help respond to fundamental rights challenges; awareness-raising activities on the EU’s Charter of Fundamental Rights; as well as analysing challenges and threats to civil society’s role and space in the EU. The FRA strategic plan was developed drawing on input from the Agency’s in-house experts. It was adopted by the FRA’s Management Board, following strategic reflections with its members. Its board is made up of independent human rights experts appointed by each EU Member State and the Council of Europe, as well as representatives of the European Commission.

title: 2018 Conference for Operational Heads of Airports
text: The conference reviewed operational activities in 2017 and examined current operational challenges. FRA contributed to the conference by presenting relevant findings of its report ‘Under watchful eyes – biometrics, EU IT-systems and fundamental rights’.

title: Sharing FRA findings with UN human rights monitoring systems
text: The discussions covered the nature and format of FRA’s regular submissions of its published findings to these mechanisms. It was of particularly interest to those with upcoming reviews of or visits to EU Member States. FRA also further explored technical aspects in relation to developing its European Union Fundamental Rights Information System with representatives of UN’s human rights office, the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, and the International Labour Organization (ILO). The system will be an online tool which will retrieve information and data from the UN, Council of Europe, and EU. While in Geneva, FRA also met the civil society organisation, UPR-info, to discuss their online tool related to the Universal Periodic Review.

title: Roma civil monitoring project workshop for NGOs
text: FRA also presented the key features of the sample survey methodology and importance of the NGOs involvement in surveys on Roma and Travellers. The workshop is aimed at NGOs involved in the EU-wide Roma Civil Monitoring Project that is being funded by the EU. The project is being led by the Central European University in Budapest in cooperation with the NGOs and NGO coalitions across the EU. It aims at building capacities of the Roma civil society and strengthening its involvement in the monitoring of national Roma integration strategies.

title: European Parliament hearing discusses interoperability
text: Also Europol was invited to present its opinion on the proposals. The proposals foresee interoperability between existing and planned IT systems in the areas of borders, visa, asylum and police cooperation. FRA referred to the main points intended to strengthen fundamental rights safeguards. In addition, FRA referred to its suggestion to mainstream fundamental rights in the implementation and evaluation of interoperability.

title: OSCE debate covers border security and information sharing
text: The panel looked at border security and information sharing. It particularly focused on OSCE activities to counter the threats posed by the return of foreign terrorist fighters. FRA presented some fundamental rights safeguards as relevant for the discussions, drawing from its recent report ‘Under watchful eyes – biometrics, EU IT-systems and fundamental rights’.

title: EU Justice and Home Affairs agencies meet
text: The meeting was also attended by other agencies such as Frontex, EASO, Europol and Eurojust. FRA contributed to the discussions by referring to the findings and opinions in its report ‘Under watchful eyes – biometrics, EU IT-systems and fundamental rights’ and its legal opinion on interoperability.

title: Challenging misconceptions about the Istanbul Convention
text: FRA’s EU-wide survey on violence against women clearly demonstrated that all EU Member States need to do more to protect women from violence. The Council of Europe is actively challenging some of the misconceptions related to the Convention to help ensure that more countries will ratify it. The event took place in Brussels on 25 April. It was organised by Friedrich Ebert Stiftung’s EU office to discuss some of the challenges, which the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (Istanbul Convention) has faced in the EU Member States which have not yet ratified it. Representatives from FRA, the Council of Europe, the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European Women’s Lobby and the Bulgarian Permanent EU Representation all took part in the event.

title: Supporting Romania prepare for its EU Presidency
text: In the context of this visit, he met the Romanian Secretary of State for Bilateral and Strategic Affairs in the Euro-Atlantic Area, George Ciamba, on 16 April to explore how FRA can best support Romania with fundamental rights advice and expertise during its Presidency of the EU Council. The meeting served to underline Romania’s commitment to defending and promoting fundamental rights during its Presidency. Romania also pledged to continue to support the Agency and its work on advancing fundamental rights at the EU and national level. While in Romania, the Director also gave a public lecture hosted by the National University of Political Science and Public Administration and met with national human rights institutions during his visit.

title: Conference on political participation of women with disabilities
text: It also chaired a discussion on how to increase cooperation among women’s groups. The conference sought to promote the political participation of women with disabilities. It was organised by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe’s Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights.

title: EU Justice and Home Affairs Agencies network focuses on gender statistics
text: Representatives from different agencies discussed the general framework for gender statistics. They also covered the benefits of making data more gender sensitive and the need for gender mainstreaming. FRA presented how it applies gender measurements in its large-scale and small-scale surveys, the approach it takes in qualitative research, as well as some research findings in relation to gender.

title: UN expert seminar focuses on the human rights of older people
text: Experts including the Agency joined the event. It aimed to gather input on four themes – equality and non-discrimination; violence, neglect and abuse; autonomy and independence and long term and palliative care. The input collected will then be discussed at the next meeting of the UN open-ended working group on ageing in July 2018.

title: CIVEX annual dialogue focuses on migrant experiences
text: It took place in Brussels on 11 April and FRA presented findings from its second EU-wide minorities and discrimination survey. The annual dialogues have been taking place since 2009. They are an opportunity to discuss policy actions at the level of the EU and the Member States, as well as to explore ways for developing cross-sectoral and multi-level coordination.

title: Addressing anti-Gypsyism during EU Roma week
text: Drawing on the Agency’s new report on anti-Gypsyism, he outlined the nature and scale of the issue. He also spoke about discrimination and harassment as manifestations of anti-Gypsyism. Reference to the importance of FRA data was made by numerous speakers throughout the EU Roma week events, including the European Commission and Members of the European Parliament. FRA also participated in other EU Roma Week events of the in Brussels, including a presentation at an event at the European Economic and Social Committee on 11 April on addressing anti-Gypsyism in ethnic profiling.

title: Fundamental rights support to Italian authorities in migration hotspots
text: It contributed to the discussion on revising the standard operating procedures, including a possible annex on health with specific reference to the needs of people with vulnerabilities and unaccompanied children. The meeting was attended by representatives from the Italian Government, the European Commission’s migration support team in Italy, Frontex, EASO, UNHCR and IOM.

title: Enabling a safe space for civil society with the LIBE Committee
text: He was exchanging views with MEPs in Brussels on the findings and opinions of the Agency’s report on the challenges facing civil society organisations working on human rights in the EU. While stressing that ensuring a safe space for civil society is an EU wide issue, the Director underlined the four main problems that affect civil society across the EU. He particularly emphasised the multiple financial pressures civil society are facing. He also underlined existing good practices in Member States. Here, he welcomed the LIBE Committee’s initiative to establish a European Values instrument for supporting civil society within the EU. Following the presentation, the Committee voted on the European Parliament resolution on this instrument, that will be adopted in plenary next month.

title: Further support to Italian authorities in migration hotspots
text: The meetings particularly focused on vulnerable people and unaccompanied children. The meetings, initiated by FRA jointly with the European Commission’s Migration Support Team in Italy, addressed the identification, transmission of information and referral of vulnerable people. FRA shared its first-hand knowledge gained during observations of disembarcations and meetings with key players involved in search and rescue operations. The 9 April core Task Force group meeting was attended by the European Commission, Frontex, EASO, Europol, the Italian Ministry of Interior Department of Public Security, Guardia di Finanza, Italian Coastguard, and the Italian Navy. The 10 April meeting was expanded to local actors such as the local ‘Questura’ police, UNHCR, IOM and Save the Children in order to map the state-of-play of vulnerability handling and referral of arriving migrants in eastern Sicily.

title: Respecting rights while sharing data across EU IT systems
text: There are EU proposals to make more intelligent and targeted use of the information available in the existing and future systems. This will allow national authorities make best use of existing data, detect multiple identities and counter identity fraud, and to carry out rapid and effective checks. They propose creating a European search portal to provide a ‘one-stop shop’ for searching across multiple systems. There will be a way to search existing databases and match biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial images. A common identity repository will pool basic biographical and biometric information, such as names and dates of birth of non-EU citizens, so that they can be reliably identified. In addition, a multiple-identity detector will flag cases where one person has different identities across the different systems. To explore the impact of such systems, the European Parliament asked the Agency to provide its Opinion on the fundamental rights implications of the proposed interoperability Regulations. The suggestions include: Ensuring a clear legal basis (‘legal foreseeability’): This applies to using the common identity repository to check people’s identity. Why these police checks need to be carried out, and how, must be clearly defined at EU level. Controlling law enforcement access: Law enforcement authorities are allowed to access EU databases to fight terrorism and serious crime. This is meant to allow them to check if people are in the systems. However, police databases should always be checked first and then clearance from an independent verifier should be sought before queries to EU databases. Improving data quality: Data entry or processing errors can lead to discrimination, mistaken identity or accusations that people are hiding their identity. Member States should be obliged to correct mistakes and flag inconsistencies. The EU should also establish an EU-wide handling mechanism for accessing, correcting and deleting inaccurate personal data. Limiting the scope of use: The future European Criminal Record Information System for non-EU nationals (ECRIS-TCN) proposes including the fingerprints of all those who are guilty of offences. Depending on each Member State’s national law, these range from serious crime to misdemeanors. Such data should not be in the common identity repository as it appears to go beyond the scope of use of data stored in ECRIS-TCN system. Informing people: With interoperable systems it is more complex to inform people if and how their data are being used. The proposals should strengthen the right to information, including making the information child-friendly and in a language the person affected understands. Mainstreaming fundamental rights: Interoperability may pose fundamental rights challenges that will become known only during implementation. Therefore, monitoring and impact evaluations should explicitly also cover fundamental rights. The EU already has a number of large-scale border management IT systems with plans to create more. Some are being revised. They help deal with visas, asylum applications, as well as internal security to track those who have been refused entry into the EU or are linked to criminal offences. This Opinion advises the EU on how to avoid potential fundamental rights pitfalls in the proposed Regulations. It encourages respect for the core data protection principles of only sharing as much data as is needed and of limiting how such data are used. It also underlines the wider impact on other rights which should be recognised in the proposals. These include access to justice, the right to asylum and child rights as well as non-discrimination which is already covered. FRA issues Opinions on specific thematic topics, following requests for advice from the European Parliament, the EU Council or the European Commission. These Opinions are part of the Agency's fundamental rights assistance and expertise that it provides to EU institutions and Member States.

title: Joining discussions on Sustainable Development Goal Indicators
text: The meeting took place in Vienna from 10 to 12 April. It was hosted by the United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO). Since 2015, UN agencies have met twice a year to discuss progress they have made in collecting data for SDG indicators and to agree on the responsibilities of various parts of the UN system to facilitate the process and support the member states in their efforts. Representatives of national statistical institutes of various UN member states contributed to the discussions, presenting examples of the way SDG monitoring has been organised in their countries. Participants also discussed the activities leading to the review of the global SDG indicators in 2020. The expert group plans to organise consultations in 2019 concerning a limited number of additional indicators that could be added to the global list, as well as a consultation on the need to review the existing indicators. Based on the consultations, the 51st session of the UN Statistical Commission will decide in 2020 on changes to the global SDG framework.

title: Building up quality of life in the local area
text: It presented some reflections from its research at the local level during a panel debate on key dimensions of the local area for quality of life. The workshop in Brussels on 11 April was hosted by Eurofound. It brought together stakeholders from various areas to discuss findings from Eurofound’s working paper on quality of life in the local area, and ways forward for research and policy in this area.

title: Towards a better understanding of cybercrime
text: The expert group is looking to carry out a comprehensive study of the problem of cybercrime. This meeting from 3 to 5 April was organised by the UNODC in Vienna. It provided valuable insights for the analysis of the request of the European Parliament for FRA to develop a practical and detailed handbook providing guidelines regarding supervisory and scrutiny controls for Member States when it comes to cybercrime.

title: FRA antisemitism survey’s ambassador meet in Brussels
text: The workshop aimed at equipping them with the necessary information and creative tools to disseminate the Agency’s second survey on discrimination and hate crime against Jewish people in their respective communities. Two representatives from each of the 13 EU Member States covered by the survey participated in the workshop. They agreed on future actions that would encourage wider participation of students and young adults in the upcoming survey. During the workshop, FRA presented its work in the area of countering discrimination and hate crime in Europe, including its work on antisemitism and surveys in more detail.

title: Communicating human rights discussed with Bratislava students
text: Around 50 students discussed how the digital age has changed the way we communicate and consume news, and its effects in creating ‘echo chambers’, ‘fake news’ as well as the importance of media literacy. The students exchanged opinions regarding on how to communicate human rights and discussed FRA’s principles for communicating rights.

title: Exploring fundamental rights and the European Investigation Order
text: It was organised by the EU-funded LIVE_FOR project. It took place on 14 March in Brussels.

title: FRA and ODIHR workshop with Polish authorities focuses on hate crime
text: The aim of this workshop was to raise awareness of the need to properly record hate crimes, as well as to identify gaps in existing hate crime recording and data collection frameworks. Such workshops were already held in Estonia, Lithuania and Portugal. They form part of the activities of the Subgroup on methodologies on recording and collecting data on hate crime facilitated by FRA under the EU High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance.

title: Public administration and intelligence oversight
text: During the event the Agency presented findings from its surveillance report, particularly focusing on oversight.

title: Eurostat discusses crime and criminal justice statistics
text: The discussions addressed the quality of regular data collection, possible improvements and the need for data from new domains such as assets freezing, cybercrime, and regional data. Eurostat updated on the preparations for the survey on gender-based violence. The Agency presented some of its large-scale surveys such as the second EU minorities and discrimination survey, its fundamental rights survey of the general public, the second FRA survey on discrimination and hate crime against Jews, its data collection on Roma and Travellers, and its preparation for a LGBTI survey.

title: Focusing on young people with sensory disabilities
text: The event is organised by civil society organisations representing young people with visual and hearing impairments. FRA’s presentation focused on the accessibility barriers people with sensory disabilities in the EU continue to face. It drew on the findings of FRA’s research on political participation and independent living for people with disabilities.

title: Lisbon workshop looks at hate crime recording
text: The aim of the event was to raise awareness of the need to properly record hate crimes, to identify gaps in existing hate crime recording and data collection frameworks, and to discuss practical steps to improve these frameworks. Workshops in other Member States are planned for 2018, as one of the outcomes of the FRA-coordinated subgroup on methodologies on recording and collecting data on hate crime. The event ran from 13 to 14 March.

title: EU Agency communicators meet to exchange best practices
text: The network aims to exchange knowledge in the area of communication and stakeholder cooperation among EU Agencies and to increase their reputation and visibility. EU Agencies communication experts shared experiences and discussed a variety of of communication challenges and issues. Topcis covered included fake news and crisis communication, big data, data visualisation, and how to increase outreach and impact. FRA provided an update on progress of its communicating rights project following recent seminars. The meeting was organised and hosted by Frontex, the current chair of the network.

title: 11th Europe-Ukraine Forum looks at European labour market
text: It presented its work on severe labour exploitation during a panel on how immigration from Ukraine has changed the European labour market. The two-day Forum was attended by about 400 participants from a wide variety of backgrounds, including governments, international organisations, business, civil society, media and others. Key topics also discussed during the Forum included: European integration, the Ukraine-EU Association Agreement, development of trade, social, healthcare and education reform, energy security, cybersecurity threats and how to combat disinformation and fake news in the media.

title: FRA hosts Germany’s leading development agency
text: GIZ works in a broad area of development and cooperation related matters abroad. GIZ’s corporate values are built around equality, human rights, civic participation and corporate responsibility. FRA shared expertise on its overall work, by focusing on equality issues, and the cooperation with civil society and other international organisations

title: UN expert meeting looks at protecting the rights of migrants in the context of return
text: The one-day event was organised by the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR). It took place on 6 March in Geneva. The expert meeting was structured around under three topics: 1) lawfulness of returns; 2) voluntariness of returns; and 3) sustainability of returns. The event brought together a selection of migration and human rights experts, from international organisations (UNHCR, IOM, UNODC, UN special rapporteurs, ICRC), academia and NGOs. The expert meeting also sought to identify areas of focus for OHCHR’s future work on migration and human rights, with a view to feeding into the current negotiations on the Global Compact on Migration as well.

title: New language versions of child-friendly justice checklist available
text: This checklist is based on findings of extensive FRA studies on child-friendly justice that interviewed children and professionals about their experiences and perspectives when children are involved in judicial proceedings. Professionals can use this checklist to ask themselves what actions need to be taken to ensure that the children with whom they are in contact feel safe and comfortable to participate. The checklist will be made available in more EU official languages during the course of 2018.

title: Innovative Italian legislation updates approach to guardianship
text: The note (both in Italian and English) looks into the implementation of Italian law on protective measures for unaccompanied children in Italy. The law entered into force in May 2017. It regulates all aspects of protecting foreign unaccompanied children in Italy. For the first time in Italy, but also in the EU, a general legislative measure has been used for protecting unaccompanied migrant children. In particular, it allows youth courts to create lists of volunteer guardians for unaccompanied children. This approach could become a promising practice in the EU. It establishes a flexible guardianship system that can respond to changing needs, is less costly than a system based on professional guardians and, more importantly, actively involves society in the destination country. However, there are potential risks, particularly related to managing, supporting and overseeing a high number of people who may decide to become volunteer guardians. For the first phase of selection and training of volunteer guardians in the regions under its responsibility, the Italian Independent Authority for Children and Adolescents received support from the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) as well as other actors. These included organisations with expertise on children in migration, including FRA. The note updates the FRA’s 2015 guardianship report which outlines the key features of guardianship systems.

title: Building on FRA's positive external evaluation
text: Presenting the findings, the independent external evaluator Optimity Advisors stressed the positive nature of the evaluation, in particular the scientific quality and the comparability of results between Member States and the objectivity of the data, which was valued highly by the stakeholders interviewed. The Agency is a unique, independent and trusted centre of excellence on fundamental rights, according to the evaluation. However, to help the FRA continue to grow and increase its impact, the Agency’s Management Board recommends a number of adaptations, the Board’s Chair Sirpa Rautio underlined to the Member States’ delegations. The Board took note of the evaluation’s finding that FRA should continue doing what it does best. But it also acknowledged the strong call from stakeholders to bring the Agency’s mandate into line with the Treaty of Lisbon, thus allowing FRA to carry out work on police and judicial co-operation in criminal matters on its own initiative. This would allow the Agency to provide timely assistance and expertise to best meet the needs of its main clients, the EU institutions and Member States, in this important area of EU competence. Better promotion and protection of fundamental rights across Europe requires cooperation and is a shared endeavour between the EU and its Member States in which the FRA has a key role to play. However, this calls for adequate resources to be able to support all of the Agency’s partners and stakeholders, as the evaluation also underlined. The FRA Director Michael O’Flaherty also pointed in particular to the fact that through small but necessary adaptations, the Agency can deliver the even more robust fundamental rights support that Europe needs and that FRA’s stakeholders demand. In response to the presentations by FRA, Member States took note of the positive evaluation and many of them expressed their appreciation for the work of the Agency.

title: Popular non-discrimination legal guide updated
text: The Handbook on European non-discrimination law is a comprehensive guide to European law in this area. This new version contains recent examples of relevant case law with new chapters on multiple discrimination, hate crime and hate speech. This handbook is designed to assist legal practitioners who are not specialists in non-discrimination law to introduce them to the key issues. It is aimed at lawyers, judges, prosecutors, social workers and people who work with national authorities, non-governmental organisations and others who may be confronted with legal questions related to discrimination. It seeks to raise awareness and improve knowledge of relevant standards set by the European Union and the Council of Europe, particularly through case law of the EU’s Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. Where relevant, it also refers to the European Social Charter, other Council of Europe instruments and international UN treaties related to non-discrimination. The publication explains the context and background to European non-discrimination law. It outlines when differences in treatment are considered discriminatory, focusing on direct and indirect discrimination, harassment, hate crime and hate speech. It also touches on possible justifications for differential treatment. Non-discrimination is also looked at from different perspectives such as employment, access to welfare and social security, education, private and family life. It also analyses the various discrimination grounds - sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, disability, age, race, ethnic origin, national origin and religion or belief. In addition, it covers procedural issues. It pays special attention to the shift in the burden of proof. Other evidential questions, such as the role of statistics and other data are also explained. The handbook is available in English. Other language versions will follow. The first edition was published in 2010 with over 100,000 downloads to date. It complements other legal handbooks covering access to justice, data protection, child rights, as well as asylum, migration and borders.

title: Migrant pushbacks a growing concern in some Member States
text: Read the March 2018 highlights >> Looking at the situation across 14 EU Member States, the report reveals how in Croatia, France and Spain migrants continue to be sent back without the chance to lodge claims for international protection. In Greece, there are rising numbers of families, pregnant women and torture victims at the border between Greece and Turkey who risk being persecuted as they are forcibly ejected from the EU. For those already in the EU, recurring problems remain. In Spain for example, the reception conditions for the growing number of newly-arrived migrants remained critical and the situation appears to be getting worse. According to the Spanish Ombudsperson, mothers with babies and unaccompanied children were held in prison-like cells, and men were sleeping on the floor with no heating. There were also delays in processing asylum claims. In Greece, migration hotspots reception centres on the islands of Lesvos, Samos and Chios remain overcrowded. This is despite falling number of arrivals. Growing intolerance towards migrants is another worry. In Hungary, for example, the government’s ever stronger anti-migrant stance, has led to a hardening of attitudes among the general public towards migrants. As a result xenophobia is on the rise, according to NGOs in the country. In Germany, attacks against refugees are rising again. Overall, in 2017 there were around 2,220 attacks against refugees and their accommodation; at least 300 people were injured. There have also been attacks reported in Italy and Greece. The Agency collects data about the fundamental rights situation of people arriving in Member States particularly affected by large migration movements. This report covers 14 Member States: Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain and Sweden. FRA has published its migration overviews since September 2015.

title: Towards piloting the next EU survey on gender-based violence
text: A number of EU Member States have agreed to pre-test and pilot the survey. The countries which had already carried out qualitative pre-testing – such as expert assessments, focus group discussions and individual interviews – presented their findings, and the meeting participants discussed the implications for the questionnaire before countries pilot the survey later in 2018. Status of Women Canada – a government agency – participated in the meeting as an observer and informed the participants about their national Survey of Safety in Public and Private Spaces, and the questions on intimate partner violence embedded in the Canadian survey.

title: Civil society challenges discussed in Poland
text: The event, which was organised in cooperation with European Commission and included speakers such as Adam Bodnar, the Polish Ombudsman attracted over 60 participants from civil society organisations, international organisations and Polish government. The findings and Opinions were discussed in the context of specific situation in Poland. Civil society and government representatives encouraged the Agency to conduct more studies and engagement in this area. Overall, it was clear that civil society are struggling with a number of issues concerning access to funding, participation in decision making process and safe space. Concerns over regulatory environment were voiced by several participants.

title: FRA deinstitutionalisation reports published in easy-read
text: The three reports look at different parts of deinstitutionalisation. The first report looks at what the EU and the 28 Member States have agreed to do. The second report is about the money that is needed to help people move from institutions to live in the community. The third report looks at the lives of people with disabilities who are living independently in their local community. Printed versions of the easy-read reports will be available in the coming months.

title: New language versions of police training manual available
text: Tried and tested with different police academies in the EU, the manual is intended as a practical tool for implementing fundamental rights-based policing in the EU. It has a separate annex with eight training practices on various human rights topics. It is now available in 22 EU official languages.

title: FRA joins UN Commission on the Status of Women discussions
text: He was speaking in New York on 13 March at the UN Commission on the Status of Women where he was part of a high-level panel on accelerating the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action to achieve concrete results by 2020. He explained how the Agency works in the context of the EU, noting that the EU still has a long way to go before it can claim to have implemented the Beijing commitments. The Agency supports these efforts in various ways. For example, its ground-breaking survey on the incidence of violence against women in the EU triggered important policy responses and contributed to the EU ultimately signing the Istanbul Convention. This year the Agency will also publish survey results on the experiences of harassment and discrimination on the part of Roma and migrant women in Europe. The Director also talked about working in a better spirit of global cooperation. For example, the Agency is open to sharing its methodologies on surveying the most vulnerable women of our societies, with other regions so such surveys can be replicated. It also would like to learn from other regions globally in order to improve the EU’s own responses. This will be instrumental in helping to deliver on the Beijing commitments to deliver on the human rights dimensions of the Sustainable Development Goals. He acknowledged that in Europe we have much to learn. The Agency as part of this will be reaching out across the globe in order to identify good practices which can then be reflected in its advice to EU Member States. While in New York, FRA’s director also held bilateral meetings with on current and upcoming human rights challenges with, for example Louise Arbour, UN Special Representative for International Migration and Asa Regner, the newly-appointed Deputy Executive Director of UN Women and the UN’s Assistant Secretary General.

title: EU Justice and Home Affairs Agencies hold network meeting
text: Network representatives from nine agencies and the Commission came together to discuss this year’s priorities for joint action in the areas of freedom, security and justice, with the aim of delivering cross-agency advice and support to EU institutions and Member States. Discussions centred on the agencies’ planned joint activities on: implementing migration, asylum and border management and internal security; training and external relations. This was the first meeting under the 2018 Chair of the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE). EIGE took over from EMCDDA as Chair, and will chair the network until 31 December, before handing over to Europol who chairs in 2019.

title: Council of Europe kicks off work on Artificial Intelligence
text: The meeting discussed the upcoming work of the committee to follow up previous work on automated processing of data (particularly algorithms). It also covered a study on the impact of artificial intelligence on fundamental rights and freedoms. FRA’s participation ensures its potential work on the topic complements that of the Council. The meeting took place on 6-7 March 2018 in Strasbourg.

title: Feeding Istanbul Convention discussions in Austria
text: The discussions will feed into the discussion on the ratification and implementation of the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (Istanbul Convention) in the EU and in Austria. The event introduced the most recent report on Austria from the Convention’s monitoring body. The report contains recommendations on how to ensure the right of women and girls to have a violence free life.

title: EU-MIDIS II survey presented to international academic network
text: The presentation focused on its second EU-MIDIS survey and how it was carried out. It was given in Warsaw during a three-day training course run by the EU-funded International Ethnic and Immigrant Minorities Survey Data Network. The course aimed at sharing knowledge on surveys of ethnic and migrant minorities among academic researchers.

title: Arts, rights and justice
text: There are currently worldwide known cases of artists and authors whose artistic freedom is violated. Civil society and individuals are increasingly getting together to establish monitoring mechanisms to make such cases heard. It also allows them to formulate empowerment responses and to find allies as human rights defenders to better protect space for artists. FRA also held a bilateral meeting with the chair of the EU’s Arts Rights Justice group to map potential long-term cooperation with FRA. There were also discussions on a set of focused activities to raise awareness of artistic freedom and human rights with the possibility of two workshops at FRA’s Fundamental Rights Forum in September.

title: Lessons learned on how to communicate human rights with impact
text: Key issues such as the need to be less institutional in communications were discussed. Examples included avoiding excessive length, jargon or technical language, acronyms or references to specific laws only known by a specialists. Other tips and know-how that can make an impact on how, why, where and by whom we communicate for impact were shared.

title: Council of Europe experts examine European immigration detention rules
text: The committee aims at codifying existing European rules and standards on administrative detention of migrants. The Agency has been part of the committee since autumn 2016 and also took part in this meeting. The Committee thoroughly examined the restructured and overhauled second version of the draft codifying instrument. The committee will continue until the end of 2018 with the next meeting due to take place in May in Strasbourg.

title: FRA cooperation with EEA-Norway Grants deepens in Greece
text: The meeting identified needs, challenges and possible areas of intervention for the programme. FRA will be involved at the project level on measures to reinforce the capacity of the Greek Ombudsman office.

title: FRA meets OSCE’s Transnational Threats Department
text: The department’s activities include actions against terrorism, border security and management, strategic police matters, cyber/ICT Security as well as POLIS, the OSCE’s online enforcement information system. The discussions covered OSCE’s recent activities in the fields of travel document security and address violent extremism and radicalisation that lead to terrorism. FRA outlined its surveys and reports on migrants and minorities as well as findings from its work on profiling and biometrics. FRA also spoke about its upcoming Fundamental Rights Forum. Areas for possible cooperation were explored based on prior consultations between the OSCE Secretary General and FRA’s Director.

title: Help eradicate discrimination and violence towards women
text: To effectively tackle this issue policy makers need reliable data. It allows them to evaluate the impact of existing actions and tailor new measures for maximum effect. FRA’s comprehensive EU-wide violence against women survey provided such data. It also supported countries ratify the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence. This was the first legally binding instrument which requires countries to have laws against different forms of violence against women. The EU signed up to the Convention in 2017. It sent a further powerful signal to society of the need to promote and protect women’s rights in these turbulent times. This was also the focus of the European Commission’s 3rd annual Fundamental Rights Colloquium. Here FRA contributed by outlining human rights commitments and gave telling examples of the challenges women have faced from across the EU over the last three years. The challenges of violence, hate and discrimination are best revealed through surveys. They provide valuable insights that other official data on recorded crime may often miss. Under-reporting of incidents of discrimination, harassment and violence is common. It often masks true levels of gender based-violence. This may be especially the case for marginalised groups like migrant women and girls who are most at risk of sexual and gender-based violence. Members of ethnic minorities may also suffer because of their gender and ethnicity. In September this year, FRA will throw the spotlight on the discrimination experiences of Roma and migrant women, drawing from its second EU minorities and discrimination survey. All this points to the need for better data and the better use of existing data through cooperation and information sharing. This and other such issues will be examined at next session of the UN’s Commission on the Status of Women. One of its aims is to explore how best to accelerate implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action to achieve concrete results by 2020. Here the FRA Director will make suggestions on how best to achieve progress and lasting impact. Important steps have already taken place. Member States who have yet to ratify the Istanbul Convention should now do so to help bring an end to the suffering too many women face.

title: Joint EU Agencies declaration on harassment
text: Equality is one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is built. Gender-based violence, including sexual harassment, is one of the most extreme manifestations of inequality and discrimination. Sexual violence and harassment contradict the principle of gender equality and equal treatment. They constitute gender-based discrimination in employment. Cases of sexual harassment and bullying, while significantly underreported, are a matter of health, safety and well-being in the workplace and need to be responded to effectively and in accordance with existing laws.
