It will allow the Agency provide fundamental rights assistance and expertise to EU Member States as they design and carry out targeted programmes and projects funded by the Grants. The agreement will also help strengthen civil society fundamental rights initiatives. The Agency has cooperated with the EEA and Norway Grants since 2013 on such issues as Roma inclusion, combating hate crime and gender-based violence, and access to justice. The Grants have also supported Agency events with EU Presidencies. A recent example was a conference in November in Bratislava with the Slovak Presidency on cross-border access to justice for everyone across the EU. The EEA and Norway Grants support EU Member States that benefit from EU cohesion funds. There is a strong focus on strengthening human rights, combating social exclusion and discrimination, and related civil society initiatives. All programmes and activities funded by the EEA and Norway Grants are based on the common values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of people belonging to minorities. Both sides agreed to the administrative arrangement for cooperation between the Agency and the Financial Mechanism Office of the EEA and Norway Grants in December 2016.

title: Equalities bodies discuss multiple discrimination
text: The event was hosted by Equinet and the Belgian Institute for the Equality of Women and Men and with the support of the US Mission to the EU. The meeting provided an opportunity for members of Equinet to share the challenges in addressing intersectional discrimination, as well as good practice examples and possible avenues for working pragmatically toward combating intersectional discrimination.

title: Survey experts discuss how to represent populations
text: The goal of the workshop was to bring together survey practitioners (commercial survey organisations, Eurostat, national statistics institutes, large surveys) and academic researchers to exchange of knowledge and practice in state-of-art survey research as well as to discuss how to tackle specific sampling-related challenges across Europe.

title: Capacity-building workshop for migration hotspot staff
text: The workshop aimed at increasing the capacity of the staff to perform their responsibilities and respond to the needs on the ground. An interactive and participatory approach was followed allowing participants to discuss the challenges in their work. The Agency focused on identifying vulnerable people and protecting children. The next workshop has been planned for 19-20 December in Leros.

title: UN Secretary-General presents TOGETHER campaign in Vienna
text: The campaign seeks to underline the positive aspects of refugees and migrants, and to strengthen social ties between communities, refugees and migrants. The Agency joined other representatives of Vienna-based inter-governmental organisations, Austrian ministries and civil society organisations at the event which was held at Habibi&Hawara, a restaurant in central Vienna staffed by refugees.

title: FRA presents its migration opinions to the European Parliament
text: The new Opinions, which were requested by the European Parliament, shed light on various fundamental rights’ protection gaps, focusing on the EU’s migration hotspot approach and the impact on children of the proposed changes to the EU’s Dublin rules for determining which Member State examines applications for international protection. Presentation on the Opinion on the 'hotspots' in Greece and Italy: Presentation given on the Opinion on the impact on children of the proposal for a revised Dublin Regulation:

title: Workshop on establishing a complaints mechanism in Frontex
text: Around 60 participants from various national authorities handling police and border staff related individual complaints took part in the workshop in Brussels from 6 to 7 December. The workshop’s objectives were to map the competent authorities in the Member States, to facilitate the sharing of experiences in the handling of individual complaints and to ultimately create a cooperation and coordination mechanism with Frontex, which is currently setting up its own individual complaints mechanism in line with its revised regulation.

title: Integration Network Conference focuses on migration
text: The congress paid special attention to the integration of refugees and to the opportunities for fostering a more inclusive society. During the panel discussion on decent work for all – between the law and reality, the Agency highlighted results from its work on severe labour exploitation: workers moving within or into the EU, published in 2015. In particular, the Agency underlined how widespread impunity fosters attitudes tolerating labour exploitation of workers from other countries.

title: Conference asks if anti-Gypsyism is a lost cause
text: The event was organised by the Group of Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

title: High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance meets
text: It discussed hate crime training for law enforcement and the judiciary. It also examined the outcome of monitoring social media, which is part of the Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online. The Agency presented the results of the first meeting of the Sub-group on methodologies for recording and collecting data on hate crime, which included the terms of reference and plan of activities of the Sub-group.

title: European Parliament discussion looks at ethnic profiling
text: The Agency spoke of the need to tackle discriminatory ethnic profiling practices in law enforcement across the EU which undermine trust with ethnic minority communities and hinder intelligence based police work that respects fundamental rights. The discussion took place in Brussels on 6 December.

title: Expert meeting looks at strengthening NHRI independence
text: During the event participants, including the Agency, reviewed specific aspects of the Paris Principles related to guarantees of independence and pluralism of NHRIs, including their functional and financial independence. It was also an opportunity to identify good practices and lessons learned on strengthening and maintaining the independence of NHRIs. Participants also discussed how to follow-up on the outcomes of the meeting to provide sustainable, operational guidance on the issue of independence to NHRIs across the OSCE region.

title: Stand up for (my, your, their) rights
text: “More and more, we are seeing a crisis of values, a crisis of fundamental rights,” says FRA Director Michael O’Flaherty. “Many of the most vulnerable people in our societies are finding themselves the target of hatred that is a far cry from the rights set out in the Universal Declaration. We all have a duty to stem this erosion of the humane values that form the cornerstone of European society.” One example of this growing intolerance is the hostility towards migrants and asylum seekers, as the Agency’s latest summary of migration-related fundamental rights in selected EU Member States reveals. Hate crime incidents range from everyday harassment to arson attacks, violence, and even murder. Children are also under threat, particular migrant children. Some 30% of the migrants arriving in the EU are children, many unaccompanied. They face enormous risks along the migration route, including sexual abuse and exploitation. Once they arrive, detention of children 'for their own safety' in inadequate conditions is still a regular practice. Although Member States are making efforts to improve guardianship systems, they often remain ill-equipped to deal with the current migration situation. A recent report from the Agency also highlighted the plight of Roma in the EU and the widespread deprivation that is destroying Roma lives. Families are living excluded from society in shocking conditions, while children with little education face bleak prospects for the future. Only 30% of the Roma in FRA’s newly published survey are in paid work, compared with the average EU employment rate of 70%. Human Rights Day is celebrated on 10 December each year. This year’s campaign, ‘Stand up for someone's rights today!’, reminds us where human rights begin: “In small places, close to home - so close and so small that they cannot be seen on any maps of the world,” as Eleanor Roosevelt put it. These include the shops, factories, offices, farms and neighbourhoods where we work and live. Together, we can make a difference. For this though, we need to reaffirm our commitment to respect, promote and protect human rights for all, no matter who they are. The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights will continue to engage with its partners and stakeholders to champion fundamental rights and to provide the evidence and law-based advice needed to bring about meaningful change.

title: Data collection lack of progress impedes antisemitism fight
text: This latest report, Antisemitism: Summary overview of data available in the European Union 2005–2015, reveals large gaps in data collection on antisemitism in EU Member States, as previous overviews also noted. In addition, each Member State collects different types of data, preventing any meaningful comparison of the data collected. Nevertheless, where comprehensive data exist, they show that antisemitism remains a serious concern which demands decisive and targeted policy responses. This would not only better protect Jewish communities against antisemitism, but would also send a clear signal that across the EU the fundamental rights of all people are protected and safeguarded. Greater efforts need to be made to counter underreporting. Not only do victims and witnesses need to be encouraged to report antisemitic incidents, but the authorities need to have systems in place that would record such incidents. Continued and sustained efforts at the national, European and international levels, as well as at the level of civil society, are needed to improve data collection on hate crime, including antisemitism. However, steps in the right direction are being made. These include the European Commission’s appointment of an EU antisemitism coordinator in December 2015, alongside the Agency’s work under the EU’s High Level Group on racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance chairing a subgroup on methodologies on recording and collecting data on hate crime. National victimisation surveys, similar to the one the Agency carried out among Jews in the EU, can also help Member States gauge antisemitism and how well they are doing combating it. Taken together such evidence can paint a more complete and accurate picture of antisemitism. This is turn should allow Member States progress in their longstanding fight against antisemitism. The updated report compiles available data on antisemitic incidents collected by international, governmental and non-governmental sources, from 1 January 2005 until 31 December 2015. No official data on reported antisemitic incidents in 2015 were available for Bulgaria, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Lithuania, Malta, Portugal and Slovenia by the time this report was compiled. This is the latest in a series of 12 yearly reports on data collection on antisemitism published by FRA and its predecessor, the EU Monitoring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia (EUMC).

title: Working group on minimal standards for training on how to counter hate crime
text: The Agency presented its Compendium of Good practices for tackling hate crime and contributed to the discussion on the guiding principles for future training programmes. The meeting was part of the work of the newly set up EU High Level Group on Combating Racism, Xenophobia and Other Forms of Intolerance, which was initiated to provide further impetus to the EU and its Member States to more effectively address intolerance and hatred, and in particular prevent and counter hate crime and hate speech.

title: Fine-tuning EU’s migration approach to better safeguard rights
text: In some hotspots delays in processing applications have put pressure on facilities and local authorities. Migrants are often housed in overcrowded reception centres that are ill-equipped to keep women and children safe from violence and harassment. The lack of appropriate information also leads migrants to be uncertain and ill-informed about their legal rights. In addition, unaccompanied children are at risk of neglect and abuse or detained for their ‘own safety’ and subject to temporary guardianship systems that are ineffective. To address some of these challenges the Agency’s migration hotspots Opinion makes a number of suggestions. These include: improving information flows about procedures and the status of applications to ease tensions among migrants as well as providing translations and child-friendly information; free and greater access to legal counsel; better protection for children such as prioritising the claims of unaccompanied children, vetting staff, individual risk assessments and sufficient resources for child guardians; qualified staff who are trained how to work with children, to identify victims of trafficking and gender-based violence; and avoiding excessive use of detention for migrants who will be returned. The EU’s current Dublin rules determine which Member State is responsible to examine applications for international protection. However, applying these rules can take up to 11 months, leading to bottlenecks and leaving applicants, particularly children, in challenging circumstances. To improve the rules, the EU is proposing revisions. The Agency’s Opinion on the impact on children of the proposed revisions to the Dublin rules underlines the need to adhere to existing child rights standards. This will ensure children’s best interests are taken into account, their rights to be heard and informed are respected, and guardians, not only legal representatives, are appointed. Promoting family unity and safeguarding unaccompanied children should be prioritised while also allowing sufficient time for thorough assessments and information collection rather than using fast tracked procedures. This also means allowing new information on family members to be considered rather than using pre-determined deadlines. Both Opinions were requested by the European Parliament. The Agency’s assessment should feed into revisions to the EU’s new Dublin rules, and guide the EU and its Member States better safeguard fundamental rights in the hotspots in Greece and Italy. They complement the Agency’s regular overviews of migration-related fundamental rights challenges in selected EU Member States and its evidence-based advice. This includes its latest report on preventing border management rights violations. In 2015, the EU released its European Agenda on Migration. It included a hotspots approach where EU bodies provide frontline support to Member States swiftly identify, register and fingerprint migrants. It also proposed revising the EU’s Dublin rules to make it more effective and address existing challenges. FRA issues Opinions on specific thematic topics, following requests for advice from the European Parliament, the EU Council or the European Commission. These Opinions are part of the agency's fundamental rights assistance and expertise that it provides to EU institutions and Member States.

title: Exploring how best to tackle the challenges LGBTI refugees face
text: Many will have fled their home countries and made their way to Canada or EU Member States as LGBTI people are among the world’s most vulnerable individuals. Over 70 countries criminalise same-sex relations; seven apply the death penalty for consensual same-sex conduct. In many countries, LGBTI people face harassment, arrest, torture and beatings. Despite the fact that LGBTI people in search of international protection on grounds of gender identity and sexual orientation are often considered to belong to ‘a particular social group’ and can enter the asylum procedure, many hurdles remain in processing asylum claims of LGBTI people. There are also serious obstacles once an asylum claim is successful, when it comes to the full inclusion of LGBTI people in society. Participants examined the difficulties LGBTI refugees face gaining asylum and acceptance into society, giving examples of promising practices on the inclusion of LGTBI asylum seekers.

title: Progress on the human rights manual for the local level
text: The members discussed key topics and issues that will be part of a manual on human rights that will support elected representatives and local municipalities’ staff in implementing human rights in their work. The expert group is compiling key promising practices and will reconvene in April 2017 at the Agency to review the first draft. Chaired by the Mayor of Middelburg, the Expert Group brings together the Congress of Local and Regional Authorities, the Raoul Wallenberg Institute, local level experts and the Agency. The manual will be available in September 2017.

title: Fundamental rights and counter terrorism
text: The Agency gave the fundamental rights perspective on counter-terrorism activities, particularly the recent EU Counter Terrorism Directive. Judges, prosecutors, other practitioners and civil society organisations also took part in the conference in Trier from 1 to 2 December.

title: EU NGO Human Rights Forum unites against torture
text: The Forum was organised by the EU’s External Action Service and the civil society umbrella network, the Human Rights and Democracy Network. It brought together over 200 human rights defenders from all over the world, as well as a number of participants from Member States and EU institutions. The main topics discussed were the fight against different forms of torture globally, and how to better protect human rights defenders – and the role that the EU could play in this more proactively. The Agency brought the EU’s internal perspective, particularly in the context of migration.

title: Building local officials’ human rights capacities in Bologna
text: The initiative was part of a one-week training module on human rights organised by the municipality, the AMITIE Code project and the Bologna university. At the training, officials from various departments, learnt about human rights with a focus on inclusion of migrants and LGBTI people. They also explored ways to integrate fundamental rights into civil servants’ daily work. The toolkit was presented by Turin’s LGBTI Office in an interactive workshop. Turin and Bologna cooperated with the Agency, along with other local authorities and their representatives, during the preparation and development of the toolkit.

title: Exploring closer cooperation on Roma integration work
text: The European Commission‘s Roma unit is increasingly interested in closer cooperation in the area of monitoring. The Agency‘s possible contribution to the Commission‘s 2017 Communication and the finalisation of the online tool for collecting information for the Member States’ annual reporting on Roma integration meaures were also explored. A number of National Roma Contact Points expressed interest in synergies with the Agency‘s planned data collection work for 2017. Country-launches of selected Roma findings from the second EU minorities and discrimination survey that were recently published were also discussed.

title: Conference looks towards more agile social statistics
text: The Agency spoke during the session ‘Statistics on asylum and migration', presenting its work on the second EU minorities and discrimination survey as an example of specialised surveys on migrant discrimination and related topics. The speakers at the conference were high-profile policy makers, academics, and statistical experts from Europe and around the world. The sessions addressed topics such as the use of new data sources in social statistics, the future of population statistics, combining and estimating data, new ways of monitoring labour mobility and transitions, more relevant statistics on asylum and migration, and more flexible and timely statistical outputs.

title: Developing rights-based indicators for regional development
text: The meeting served to support managing authority for ‘regional development’ define guidelines, selection criteria, and rights-based indicators. The workshop was a follow-up to the two training sessions the Agency provided in July and October. The Commission are looking for opportunities (and Agency support) in applying rights-based indicators in their work.

title: FRA meets future Maltese Presidency Chairs of Council preparatory bodies
text: This provided an opportunity for the Agency to introduce its work to in such areas as asylum and integration, rights of the child, countering terrorism, and criminal law. Further contacts are envisaged in the course of the Maltese Presidency.

title: European Asylum Support Office’s Consultative Forum meets
text: This annual event brings together representatives from civil society and other selected actors. For the first time the meeting was held in Athens. This allowed participation by civil society actors working in Greece. A participatory methodology was used by EASO which was very successful in collecting concrete ideas for action from participants. The 2016 Consultative Forum marked a turning point in EASO’s collaboration with civil society.

title: European Roma Platform meeting hears of widespread Roma poverty
text: He spoke of how 80% of Roma surveyed are at risk of poverty compared with an EU average of 17%. He underlined how this is a primorial violation of fundamental rights. To help tackle such issues policy makers require data, which the Agency’s survey provides. The findings fed into discussions among a broad range of stakeholders as they discussed progress in implementing the EU Framework of National Roma Integration Strategies up to 2020.

title: FRA to provide fundamental rights expertise to Greek authorities
text: The Agency will share expertise and best practices with the Ministry concerning fundamental rights issues connected to the reception and identification of newly arrived migrants and asylum seekers. This will particularly focus on initial reception, identification and registration procedures, identification and referral of people with specific protection needs such as unaccompanied children, suspected victims of trafficking and vulnerable people, reception conditions, child protection safeguards, respect for the right to be heard and the right to an effective remedy. In this context, the Agency, in cooperation with the UN Refugee Agency, UNHCR, will train staff from the Greek Reception and Identification Service in the hotspots. Training has been planned for 8-9 December in Kos and 19-20 December 2016 in Leros.

title: Protecting children in migration under the spotlight at European child rights forum
text: He was speaking about the challenges and opportunities for protecting children in migration. To frame the issue he mentioned the one million people arrived in EU in 2015 of which 30-40% were children, many unaccompanied. He spoke of guardianship systems in EU being not equipped to deal with current migration crisis. He acknowledged changes are being made but slowly. To better help children, he underscored the importance of learning from each other: “Somewhere, someone in the EU is getting child rights right”. The event brought together more than 250 participants representing EU member states, international organisations, NGOs and academics. It promoted good practices in the area of identification and protection, reception, access and treatment in the asylum procedures, and integration of children. At the Forum, the Agency also took part in a dedicated side-event on guardianship for unaccompanied and separated children will also. It provided an overview of national guardianship systems in EU Member States and expert advice from the handbook on guardianship for children deprived of parental care.

title: Driving change: Marking 10 years of the UN’s disability convention
text: The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights has been taking stock of how the convention has been having an impact in the EU and its Member States. Its focus paper on CRPD-inspired reforms, and the Agency’s Fundamental Rights Report both examined developments that have taken place. For example, in the last ten years, eight EU Member States have taken steps to give people with disabilities greater autonomy, and respect their will and preference by replacing substitute-decision making with laws and policies that give people with disabilities equal recognition by law. In addition, in the last two years, over 10 EU Member States have adopted CRPD-relevant strategies and action plans. The EU, itself having signed the convention, has also taken steps to fulfil its obligations. It has changed EU financing rules under its European Structural and Investment Fund to ensure accessibility improvements are a condition for receiving money. Civil society organisations must also be part of the planning, implementation and monitoring of such EU-funded projects in their Member State, giving a voice to disabled people’s organisations.  In addition, just two months ago, the European parliament adopted a Directive on the accessibility of public sector websites. A European Commission proposal for a wider Accessibility Act is also currently being discussed by the EU Council. These are some of the steps the EU is taking to fulfil the recommendations it received from the UN’s CRPD Committee in 2015. Further steps will be taken by the EU, some of which will be set out in the update of the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 that will be published by the end of 2016. The EU’s CRPD Framework, chaired by the Agency, will also help guide the EU when it comes to implementing the CRPD. The convention has also had a much wider reach. It is spearheading a drive to a human-rights based approach to disability globally. The UN’s new 15-year plan for global development – the Sustainable Development Goals – includes the needs of people with disabilities for the first time. Four areas in particular have been singled out: inclusive education; reducing inequality; promoting full employment; and ensuring accessibility for all. Not only that, when tracking the goals’ progress, the data being collected will also specifically identify people with disabilities. In only 10 years, the convention has already made a mark in helping to improve the rights and lives of people with disabilities across the EU. As the convention’s in-built review mechanism takes effect in more and more countries, it will continue to drive change and further empower people with disabilities.

title: 10 practical tips to prevent border management rights violations
text: The guidance has been published together with the report ‘Scope of the principle of non-refoulement in contemporary border management: evolving areas of law’. It was developed based on consultations with experts at a meeting at the Agency on 14 March 2016. It will enable Member States take effective action to manage external borders in line with the non-refoulement principle of not returning people to places where they risk persecution or other serious harm. The report contains suggestions that will help Member States meet fundamental rights obligations when carrying out border management beyond their territorial borders. The suggestions include: Conduct a prior assessment and monitor the human rights situation in the third country. Clarify responsibilities and procedures in arrangements concluded with third countries. Refrain from asking third countries to intercept migrants in case of real risk of harm. Provide fundamental rights training to staff deployed in third countries. Offer human rights training to third-country officials. Clarify responsibilities in operational plans. Embed fundamental rights in capacity-building activities. Take decisions on an individual basis applying appropriate safeguards. Disembark people rescued at sea in a place where they are safe. Facilitate access to international protection at borders. Throughout the report different scenarios for what constitutes non-refoulement violations are examined. They look at the situation at sea, at the EU’s external borders and in non-EU countries. For each scenario, the laws, current practices, and arguments for and against finding a violation of non-refoulement are outlined. For instance, EU Member States that ask non-EU countries to prevent refugee arrivals on their behalf may be liable if rights violations occur.

title: National human rights bodies discuss the UN’s disability convention
text: The meeting allowed for sharing of information on national developments and good practices as well as discussions on the challenges. The event was followed by a one-day seminar on Article 13, access to justice, of the CRPD.

title: Exploring how best to communicate on migration
text: The focus of discussions was on communicating about migration, refugees and integration. The Agency’s Director gave a speech underlining the importance of empirical data and the need to challenge migration myths. He made reference to the Agency’s monthly migration updates that have been telling the story of human rights deprivation in frontline Member States. He also mentioned how media literacy is vital to ensure that the public fully understands the migrant situation. As the media have been instrumental in telling the story of migration into and across Europe, the Agency is developing a toolkit for media professionals which will also include communicating about migration. The Agency also moderated a session on communicating about integration. The seminar looked at several aspects related to migration and see exactly how these messages have been delivered, with examples of effective tools and storytelling about migration and integration, to assess what impact these experiences have had and how the person or channel delivering the message has influenced the outcome, if at all. The event brought together communications and media representatives of the EESC's host organisations, its members, National Economic and Social Committees and similar bodies, as well as other EU institutions, journalists and journalist organisations.

title: Information systems and interoperability expert group meets
text: The Agency, a member of the group, spoke about the fundamental rights safeguards that need to be taken on board in developing any interoperable system for data exchange and alerts based on existing migration databases such as SIS, VIS and Eurodac. The Agency will continue to work with the High Level Expert Group in the coming year.

title: Capacity-building on fundamental rights, citizenship and learning from the Holocaust
text: The event was opened by Lucia Zitnanska, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Justice of the Slovak Republic. Around fifty participants, teachers and government officials from all EU Member States took part, exploring the lessons from the Holocaust, while learning for fundamental and human rights today. In addition to its main goal to build capacity of public officials, the event achieved high political attention and media coverage.

title: FRA surveillance and fundamental rights safeguards report presented to Council Working Party
text: It presented the findings of its report on surveillance by intelligence services: fundamental rights safeguards and remedies in the EU.

title: Refugee children: protecting and promoting their right to education
text: The meeting focused on the integration of refugee children in education and related challenges with a particular focus on local authorities. Local and regional authorities are key actors to facilitate and provide education for migrants, displaced people, refugees and stateless children. Non-discrimination plays a central role in enabling the children of migrants to access education. The meeting explored how local authorities can support the education of refugee children and participants shared experiences and best practices. The Agency presented its data and expertise in the area of asylum-seeking children and migrant children more broadly, building on its monthly overviews of migration-related fundamental rights issues. Since 2009, the Annual Dialogue has been a platform to discuss fundamental rights themes of relevance at the regional and local level, and to share knowledge of existing fundamental rights good practices.

title: European Network of Legal Experts in Gender Equality and non-Discrimination meets
text: The meeting took place on 24 November in Brussels, It was followed by a European Commission legal seminar where the latest developments in the area of Equality and Non Discrimination were discussed.

title: Videos to help raise children’s rights awareness
text: The seminars targeted professionals who interact with children in judicial proceedings. In Trier, the Academy of European Law Judges seminar reached out to lawyers and legal counsellors while the online seminar organised by the European Police College (CEPOL) focused on police officers and prosecutors. During both seminars, the professionals stressed the importance of informing children about their rights and the usefulness of child-friendly material, for example the Agency’s videos on children and justice, on the right to be heard, the right to protection and legal representation and the right to information.

title: FRA media toolkit kicks off
text: The meeting took place at the European Commission ahead of the Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights on ‘Media Pluralism and Democracy’, where it was announced that the toolkit will cover a broad range of fundamental rights issues. It will be developed in close collaboration with media stakeholders. The toolkit will include practical tips and information sources for journalists covering news in different media genres related to a range of fundamental rights issues, for example asylum and migration, discrimination and hate crime.

title: Slovenian presentation of Fundamental Rights Report 2016
text: The alternate member of the Agency’s Management Board, and representatives from civil society organisations, academia and national authorities attended the event. The conference allowed former and recent members of the national equality body, representatives of national authorities, academia and civil society representatives to exchange their views in regards to the new Anti-discrimination Act. The conference aimed at raising the visibility and awareness of the Fundamental Rights Report in Slovenia.

title: Exploring the results from FRA’s violence against women survey
text: The Agency had been invited by the City of Kaiserslautern and its Europe Direct Information Centre, together with the Atlantic Academy Rheinland-Pfalz invited to explain its findings. The Agency spoke about the prevalence, causes and effects of different forms of gender based violence by putting the results for Germany in comparison to EU average and to other EU Member States. It also explained the various factors that can lead to the observed country differences.

title: Czech and German versions of the access to justice legal handbook
text: This handbook seeks to raise awareness of the relevant legal standards set by the EU and the Council of Europe, particularly through the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights. The handbook is designed to serve as a practical guide for lawyers, judges and other legal practitioners involved in litigation in the EU and in Council of Europe member states, as well as for individuals who work for non-governmental organisations and other entities that deal with the administration of justice. Further language versions of the handbook should be soon available.

title: International rights experts explore human rights promotion
text: The Rafto Foundation for Human Rights is a non-profit and non-partisan organisation dedicated to the global promotion of human rights. The Forum gathered a powerful group of Rafto Laureates and prominent international human rights experts with the aim of shedding light on key human rights issues, identifying new trends and initiating joint activities. On 22 November, Michael O’Flaherty was in Oslo and gave a public lecture on the main human rights challenges in the EU today. He also met with the Norwegian National Human Rights Institute, where he presented the work of the Agency and discussed the role of NHRIs.

title: Germany discusses reviewing its access to health of trans people legislation
text: The discussions in Berlin dealt with the reform of the law and guidelines regulating access to health of Tans persons, to be based on the work of the Inter-ministerial Working Group established by the Federal government to deal with Trans issues. The Agency presented relevant findings from its analysis of the transgender component of its 2013 EU-wide LGBT survey, its 2015 LGBTI comparative legal analysis, and its 2015 research among public officials and key professional groups.

title: Migrant women and girls face heightened risk of violence
text: Over the past year, the Agency has been collecting data on the fundamental rights situation of people arriving in Member States particularly affected by large migration movements. In June, the monthly report focused on gender-based violence. The report highlights various realities and threats that women and girls face once they are in the EU. While all of the nine EU countries looked at in the Agency’s report have one or more measures in place to protect female asylum seekers, very few have comprehensive responses. The realities on the ground can mean inadequate provision of separate accommodation for males and females, problems with separate washing facilities, and a lack of security to enhance women’s safety. In addition, provision of information on gender-based violence and how to report it is a major weakness in all Member States covered in the report. This situation increases non-reporting of abuse and allows abusers to act with relative impunity. Various EU and national laws and policies take gender-based violence into consideration when it comes to granting asylum and when receiving asylum seekers. In addition, the European Parliament has called for new gender guidelines to better protect female refugees. The European Commission has also suggested that the EU ratifies the Council of Europe’s Convention on combating violence against women and domestic violence (the Istanbul Convention), which also covers migration and asylum. This would provide a solid legal basis for addressing violence against all women. Until such initiatives materialise, the Agency’s report identifies areas Member States could address to help combat violence against migrant women and girls. These include: better information on gender-based violence and what to do if it happens; staff guidelines and training; and separate facilities for females and support for victims, including legal support. Taken together, these measures could significantly help eliminate violence against migrant women and girls seeking sanctuary in the EU. These results complement the detailed picture provided by the Agency’s EU-wide survey on violence against women, which looked at the extent and nature of various forms of violence against women in the general population.

title: Social and civic competences discussed in Commission Working Group
text: As part of the strategic framework of education and training 2020, the working group supports the Member States in implementing the Paris Declaration. At this meeting, participants discussed ways to strengthen social and civic competences by integrating the approach of Global Citizenship Education and by exploring the need to possibly revise the definition of Social and Civic Competences from the 2006 Recommendations on key competences for lifelong learning. The meeting was also an opportunity to learn more about ongoing global citizenship education projects in several Members States. The Working Group brings together Member States representatives from education ministries as well as other actors involved in citizenship education such as the Council of Europe, ODHIR and FRA.

title: Experts discuss policy needs for data on crime
text: Differences in the way crime has been defined in law in different Member States, coupled with varying data recording systems, continue to pose a challenge for having harmonised and comparable EU statistics as an evidence base for policy makers. The Agency spoke about its surveys that have collected data on crime victimisation, as well as the recent reports in the area of justice. The European Commission mentioned its plans to present its new action plan on crime statistics in 2017 for 2016-2020, building upon the work carried out under previous actions plans 2006-2010 and 2011-2015.

title: New language versions of the child rights legal handbook available
text: It aims to raise awareness and improve the knowledge of the legal standards that protect and promote children’s rights in Europe.

title: Experts discuss measuring violence against women
text: Experts discussed at a meeting from 16 to 17 November in Vilnius the scope of indicators on violence against women and how to integrate data with the Gender Equality Index. The Agency’s data on violence against women is the most comprehensive and only comparative data source available and is key to the new measurement framework.

title: Identifying integration challenges and opportunities
text: It drew on the findings from the Agency’s research into migrant participation and inclusion. In the speech, the importance of building a (business) case for the positive aspects of diversity that can attract support for integration among mainstream society was covered. It underlined how equal treatment regardless of racial or ethnic origin is not just a policy goal to facilitate integration but rather a legal obligation. The Agency also spoke about the need for Member States to find practical and actionable ways to overcome segregation in schooling as this risks creating separate social spaces. They also need to foster a sense of 'belonging'; one way of doing this is could be by promoting an active political participation of established non-EU nationals, for example through voting in local elections. As a final point, it raised awareness of the need to avoid incidents of racial discrimination masquerading as differential treatment based on the ground of 'nationality', which is unprotected in some Member States.

title: 5th Annual UN Business and Human Rights Forum
text: The theme was leadership and leverage: Embedding human rights in the rules and relationships that drive the global economy. A great number of panel discussions and bilateral meetings contributed to the ongoing work on the Agency’s opinion on business and human rights – the right to remedy. While in Geneva, the Agency also presented its work to staff at the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, in preparation for upcoming country visits and review of state reports related to EU Member States.

title: FRA attends Annual Media Literacy Expert Group
text: The meeting, organised by the European Commission, explored synergies between the different EU policies and highlighted the Commission’s strategic support to programmes and media literacy initiatives across the EU. At the meeting, the Commission expressed its concern for the lack of media literacy skills among the general public; only 2% appears to use critical thinking while searching for information online, which is considered an impediment for the full participation of citizens in the society. From this point of view, the Commission announced a considerable increase of grants in 2017 on media literacy projects.

title: Mainstreaming fundamental rights: Case studies based on the fundamental rights-based police training manual
text: The Agency presented its Compendium of Good practices for tackling hate crime, its Fundamental rights-based police training manual and the state of play at the EU level concerning hate crime legislation. The overall aim of the workshop was to provide law enforcement officials with up-to-date information in identifying hate crime, including hate speech, and in taking appropriate actions to investigate these crimes.

title: European LGBTI governmental focal points meet
text: It was co-organised by the Council of Europe and the Estonian chairmanship of the Council of Europe. The Agency took part in a panel debate on trans and intersex children and youth, chaired a workshop on LGBTI refugees and represented the Agency as an observer in the network. During the meeting, the Agency also met with the newly appointed UN Independent Expert on the protection against violence and discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, Vitit Muntarbhorn.

title: Inter-Service group on integrating third-country nationals meets
text: The meeting discussed the current situation monitoring the implementation of the Action Plan for Integration of Immigrants. The European Commission and EU Agencies, such as FRA and the European Gender Institute (EIGE), shared information and informed about past, current and planned key actions and initiatives across the EU supporting the Member States promoting and integrating immigrants.

title: Intergovernmental LGBTI focal point network meets
text: It addressed the plenary session which focused on the human rights challenges of transgender and intersex children and young people in everyday life. It also joined discussions on LGBTI Refugees during a thematic session.

title: Council of Europe Roma expert committee meets
text: The meeting took place from 15 to 18 November at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg. On 15 November, it spoke during a session on EU and Council of Europe joint programmes and cooperation. It provided an update on its Structure-Process-Outcome indicators template for measuring progress in implementing national Roma integration strategies. It also covered developments and forthcoming outputs of the Agency’s Local Engagement for Roma Inclusion (LERI) project. The upcoming launch of the Roma summary results report from the EU minorities and discrimination survey at the end of November 2016 was also highlighted. The Agency also joined several side events, including coordination meetings between international intergovernmental institutions and one organised by the European Commission. On 17 November, the Agency met with local fieldwork experts and stakeholders involved in the LERI project in Strasbourg, one of the project’s field sites. The project implementation and case study from Strasbourg were discussed in advance of the end of project conference in Vienna early December.

title: Protecting media freedom and democracy
text: "We have to acknowledge that we will play a constant game of catch-up. We are never going to have a totality of knowledge and understanding and related wisdom. Technology will always stay ahead of law and social policy," he said, opening the session 'Protecting journalists and their freedom of expression' on the second day of the Colloquium. "We don’t need more basic international human rights law with regard to the issues at play. What we need is better attention to and understanding of, delivery of, implementation of and better framing of the issues in the categories of international human rights law." This point was echoed by Françoise Tulkens, a former Judge and Vice-President of the European Court of Human Rights and a member of FRA’s Scientific Committee. “We don’t need more law but more enforcement, more respect for court rulings,” she said during the same session. It was suggested during the session that in order to defend media freedom in its broadest sense, the EU and its Member States could adopt a multi-stakeholder approach that brings together all those already active in the field. In this regard, some kind of inter-institutional framework could be put forward. Fostering a vibrant civil society can also ensure that government authorities or the private sector cannot limit media freedom with impunity. Speaking on the first day of the Colloquium, FRA’s Director also talked about the responsibility of journalists and all those with a public voice not to incite hatred. A second FRA paper published on the occasion of the Colloquium that covers incitement in media content and political discourse shows that "16 Member States report incitement in the media, which is typically aimed at minority groups in this societies. The study of FRA shows inadequate policing within this field, in terms of criminal prosecution, the proceedings towards incitement are not consistently carried out." The EU could play a useful role in "soft approaches to deal with and challenge incitement in the media," he added. The Colloquium focused this year on media pluralism and democracy. It underlined the vital role free media plays underpinning democracy, and respect for human rights and the rule of law.

title: Migrant hate widespread, reveals Fundamental Rights Agency report
text: Access the focus section on hate crime and the monthly data collection highlights. The report identifies serious and widespread incidents of violence, harassment, threats and hate speech towards migrants and asylum seekers, and their children, across 14 EU Member States. Human rights advocates, ‘pro-refugee’ politicians and journalists have also been targeted. It points to some of the perceived perpetrators, and highlights the problem of under-reporting and under-recording of hate crime which impedes efforts to find effective responses. Some of the main findings include: Most Member States do not collect or publish statistical data on hate crime incidents against asylum seekers and migrants; civil society often are the main sources of information. Vigilantes and the general public are often behind the attacks. Offline and online hate speech, including by public figures who sometimes even condone attacks, is fuelling open intolerance. This intolerance is spilling over to other parts of society with Muslims, especially women, and people from ethnic backgrounds, particularly targeted. Asylum seekers and migrants rarely report hate crimes to authorities or other organisations for a number of reasons. These include: a lack of trust in the police and public authorities; fear of arrest, being deported or of retaliation; a belief that nothing will change; and language barriers. Under-reporting also leads to the issue being buried. State responses to hate crime against asylum seekers and migrants are perceived as weak by civil society in many Member States. Victim support services that meet the needs of asylum seekers and migrants are rare. Asylum seekers and migrants also have limited access to existing support. EU laws offer protection to victims and the Agency has compiled information about various initiatives that tackle hate crime in the EU. However, Member States lack the robust data they need to prevent hate crime, and protect and promote the rights of migrants and asylum seekers in an increasingly openly intolerant Europe. The European Commission asked the Agency to collect data about the fundamental rights situation of people arriving in Member States, particularly affected by large migration movements. As of this month, the reports cover the situation in 14 Member States: Austria, Bulgaria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia, Spain and Sweden. FRA has published overviews since September 2015. Each overview covers such issues as: initial registration and asylum applications; criminal proceedings initiated for offences related to irregular border crossings; child protection; reception conditions for new arrivals; access to healthcare; public response such as rallies of support, humanitarian assistance or voluntary work; racist incidents such as demonstrations, online hate speech or hate crime. Next month the focus will be on separated children.

title: Children face high risk of sexual exploitation
text: Over the past year, the Agency has been collecting data on the fundamental rights situation of people arriving in Member States, particularly affected by large migration movements. The monthly reports consistently point to inadequate reception facilities often resulting in incidents of abuse, sexual assault and children going missing. The findings underline the need for specific measures to protect children from violence. This includes training staff to identify children at risk and having clear and efficient guardianships procedures that can offer children protection. However, migrant children are not the only ones at risk. The problem is much wider than that. Results from FRA’s violence against women survey underlined the scale of childhood abuse throughout the EU. Some 12% of women had experienced sexual violence by an adult before they were 15 years old. Prevention is therefore of paramount importance. Greater efforts and emphasis should be placed on identifying risks of abuse and taking action to minimise these risks. These include training to help staff in social, health and education services spot potential risks factors, identifying at risk families, home visits, and additional safeguards for children in reception and detention centres. Given the prevalence of such abuse there is a strong need for procedural safeguards during judicial proceedings. Concrete measures on a child’s right to be informed, to be heard and to be protected should be made standard practice. This includes ensuring that there are no possibilities of meeting defendants and their families before, during and after hearings. This does not just apply to hearings but also in the waiting areas or when entering or leaving court buildings, as the Agency’s research has shown. Soon the Agency will also provide a report on the views of children in judicial proceedings. Taken together, it is clear greater safeguards are needed to prevent sexual exploitation and abuse of children and protect them from harm.

title: EU workshop on migration data
text: The meeting gathered participants from various European Commission Directorates General and EU Agencies to discuss the availability of migration data as well as data sharing practices. The aim was to keep up-to-date about the upcoming launch of products from the European Commission’s Knowledge Centre on Migration and Demography. It was also an opportunity to share information about different data collections and data sharing practices of EU bodies.

title: Strengthening ties with the Council of Europe’s violence against women expert body
text: The expert body was interested to hear about the range of FRA’s work on violence against women. This included the Agency’s large-scale survey on violence against women through to the more recent collection and publication of data on the asylum crisis as it relates to several EU Member States which focused on gender-based violence. The Agency will continue to assist the Council of Europe in their monitoring work by exchange information with them.

title: Exploring children’s rights in alternative care
text: The Agency spoke of the human rights obligations underpinning the provision of alternative child care and outlined some of the Agency’s findings which underline the need for systematic training of all those involved in alternative care, including foster parents. The Agency considers that the respect and protection of child rights require better operational coordination of the different actors involved in alternative care settings, as well as more effective interagency cooperation and multidisciplinary practices.

title: Fundamental rights discussed as part of EU coast guard cooperation
text: The met in Warsaw with the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex) and other EU and international actors to step up joint collaboration and strengthen European cooperation on coast guard functions. Together with the European Asylum Support Office and the UNHCR, the Agency took part in a panel debate discussing the fundamental rights dimension of maritime border management in the context of the current migratory flows.

title: Equality Bodies discuss combating race and ethnic discrimination
text: The event was hosted by Equinet and the Office of the Commissioner for Fundamental Rights in Hungary. The Agency provided meeting participants information concerning the agency’s second EU-wide minorities and discrimination survey (EU-MIDIS II). As the first results of EU-MIDIS II concerning Roma will be launched on 29 November with further results available in 2017 and beyond, the discussions concerning the type of data that will be available will help identify and plan opportunities for presenting the results at national and European level. It will also contribute to finding opportunities to use the survey results in Equinet’s and the Equality Bodies’ work. The meeting allowed members of Equinet to exchange information on how incidents of discrimination are dealt with within the varying mandates of different Equality Bodies. It was also a chance to discuss the draft working paper on fighting discrimination on grounds of race and ethnic origin, prepared by the Equinet working group on equality law.

title: EU Agencies’ Network on Scientific Advice meets
text: The network comprises 11 EU agencies that undertake scientific research and analysis for institutions and national authorities in Europe. It meets twice a year to exchange information and expertise on the advancement of science and research for EU policy and regulatory frameworks.

title: A key to finding a sustainable solution to the current migration crisis
text: He mentioned findings from a project the Agency is finalising on migrant participation. They reveal how the integration policies of many EU countries are ill-equipped to meet current challenges of the largest movement of people since the Second World War. He warned that if we fail on migration, which is so close to the values on which the EU was founded, Europe will have failed; we will be compromising our ability to solve future challenges.

title: FRA joins International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance meeting
text: This meeting was held under the Chairmanship of Romania. The Agency provided an update on its work on Roma, combating antisemitism and the Holocaust and human rights education. It provided input to the meeting of the Alliance’s Education Working Group, its Committee on Antisemitism and Holocaust Denial and its Committee on the Genocide of the Roma. The Agency has been a permanent international partner of IHRA since 2006.

title: Crime of Torture and National Independent Commission: is Italy still credible in the field of human rights?
text: The event looked at two human rights-related issues where Italy seeks to improve: National Human Rights Institutions and the definition of torture. The Agency contributed to the debate on the establishment of an NHRI by stressing the links between the EU and NHRIs, and the added value of an NHRI in an EU context. The event sought to add momentum to renewed attempts in the Italian parliament to pass legislation establishing an NHRI with a view to A-status accreditation.

title: Intelligence law symposium looks at control, legal protection and cooperation
text: It looked at control, safeguards and remedies and cooperation. The Agency presented its work on fundamental rights safeguards and remedies in the context of surveillance by national intelligence authorities.

title: Slovak version of the access to justice legal handbook available
text: It seeks to raise awareness of the relevant legal standards set by the EU and the Council of Europe, particularly through the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights. The handbook is designed to serve as a practical guide for lawyers, judges and other legal practitioners involved in litigation in the EU and in Council of Europe member states, as well as for individuals who work for non-governmental organisations and other entities that deal with the administration of justice. Additional language versions should be available soon.

title: New language versions of the fundamental rights-based police training manual
text: The compilation of practices is also available in German and Polish. The manual translates ‘high’ principles into specific practical exercises that facilitate police work, and supports police officers in internalising the concepts that drive human rights-based policing – helping to ensure that they are equipped to make the right choices in their daily work.

title: Latvian Ombudsman discusses European child rights law with practitioners
text: Legal professionals, including judges, lawyers, and public prosecutors, as well as police officers, social workers and other practitioners concerned with the protection and promotion of child rights in Latvia discussed the application of European standards, including ‘real’ cases brought to the attention of the Latvian Ombudsperson’s office. This also allowed the introduction of broader discussions among the practitioners regarding the application of child protection law across the EU and in Latvia in particular. The Handbook is now available in Latvian and 14 other EU languages.

title: Handbook on European law relating to the rights of the child now in Bulgarian and Italian
text: It aims to raise awareness and improve the knowledge of the legal standards that protect and promote children’s rights in Europe. Further language versions of the handbook should be soon available.

title: European Parliament discusses disability rights petitions
text: The workshop was organised by the European Parliament’s policy department for citizens’ rights and constitutional affairs. Three studies commissioned by the European Parliament’s Committee on Petitions (PETI) were presented. They focused on: the protection role of the PETI committee in the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities; the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access to published works by visually impaired people and people with print disabilities; and European Structural and Investment Funds and people with disabilities. The Agency will reflect on these studies in the second session alongside the other members of the EU Framework to promote, protect and monitor the implementation of the CRPD.

title: International conference focuses on business and human rights
text: It was organised as part of the EU-funded FRAME Fostering Human Rights Among European Policies project. The conference was organised by the University of Seville, the Leuven Centre for Global Governance Studies at the University of Leuven, and the BHRight Initiative. The conference brought together scholars from various disciplines, together with international organisations such as the International Labour Organisation, business representatives and other experts. It sought to identify and examine issues that arise in the application and conceptualisation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and the ways to bridge the gap between global business and the protection of human rights. The Agency’s presentation focused on access to remedy at the EU level and its forthcoming opinion on business and human rights.

title: FRA condemns shocking attack on human rights defender
text: “The perpetrators of this despicable act need to be urgently brought to account,” says Agency Management Board Chair Frauke Lisa Seidensticker. “With intolerance  on the rise, every effort must be made to halt this plague on society and attacks on those, like Krassimir Kanev, who valiantly fight for human rights.” “Frontline human defenders are too often victims of heinous criminal attacks for standing up for the legitimate rights of everyday people whoever they are,” added Agency Director Michael O’Flaherty. “The Agency strongly condemns the assault on Krassimir Kanev. We will continue to work hand-in-hand with all those who are actively fighting to promote and protect human rights.” The Bulgarian Helsinki Committee is the largest organisation for protecting human rights in Bulgaria. It strives to promote respect for human rights of every individual across the country.

title: FRA exchanges views with European Parliament on employment and human rights
text: Although the experts interviewed by FRA reported that they regularly note cases of severe labour exploitation, offenders are seldom convicted. There is a system of impunity that rests on three pillars: a fragmentation of criminal law provisions, a lack of monitoring (in particular a lack of inspections from labour inspectorates), and a lack of proactive police investigations. Building on its 2015 report, the Fundamental Rights Agency will continue its research in 2017 by carrying out face-to-face interviews with foreign workers in the EU who have been exploited for their labour. This research will fill a significant gap in research on the subject, and will provide legislators, policy makers and those responsible for combating severe labour exploitation at EU and national level with the evidence necessary to further develop effective measures to counter severe labour exploitation. Moving on to discuss the Roma, Michael O’Flaherty presented new data from the Fundamental Rights Agency’s survey of Roma across nine EU Member States, which will be published at the end of this month. He emphasised that the Roma employment rate is much lower than among the general population, while the gap between young Roma not in employment, education or training and their peers around the EU is still larger. In closing, the Director pointed out that in the area of disability, the EU has a disability employment gap of some 23 percentage points, with only 48% of people with impairments in employment. This persistently large gap shows the need for more systematic and ambitious action on the part of the EU and its Member States. Following his remarks, the Director had a constructive exchange of views with members of the Committee. The MEPs present expressed a strong interest in the issue of severe labour exploitation, and stressed the need to put social and economic rights higher up the EU agenda. Many voiced the opinion that EU Member States need to be more active in tackling labour exploitation by increasing transnational cooperation in this area. Watch the Director's remarks:

title: FRA Director speaks of “frightening” tendency to question Europe’s human rights framework
text: The speech, entitled ‘Is Europe facing a crisis of human rights?’, formed part of the Director’s visit to Ireland on 24-26 October to discuss pressing fundamental rights topics and strengthen cooperation with key stakeholders. Talking about areas of growing human rights challenges, the Director pointed out that anti-migrant sentiment often obscures the fact that the vast majority of those entering the EU over the last year come from war-torn countries where they could face persecution or death if they remained. He also spoke of FRA’s monthly overviews, which show alarming manifestations of hatred, including violent attacks on migrants as well as arson attacks on their accommodation. As well as meetings with Frances Fitzgerald, Tanaiste and Minister for Justice and Equality, Katherine Zappone, Minister for Children and Youth, Joe McHugh, Minister of State for the Diaspora and International Development, and David Stanton, Minister of State for Equality, Immigration and Integration, Michael O’Flaherty met Emily Logan, Chief Commissioner, Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission and Gerard Kiely, Head of the European Commission Representation. He also met the Chair of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Justice and Equality, and a number of civil society representatives. In addition to migration, they discussed human rights issues related to Travellers, equality, security and children.

title: Lessons from the past to help tackle antisemitism today
text: For example, the Agency’s 2013 survey report on Discrimination and hate crime against Jews in EU Member States revealed how 66% of respondents felt that antisemitism is a major problem in their country. Over a fifth of respondents had been physically attacked, verbally insulted and harassed in the 12 months prior to the survey. Antisemitism has also spilled online: 76% felt that online antisemitism had increased over the last five years. Concerted efforts are required from the EU, its Member States, educational practitioners and civil society organisations to combat the phenomenon. Fundamental rights promotion and wider educational efforts all play a pivotal role in this. 	Holocaust and human rights education can help teach those in the present about citizenship and remembrance by drawing on lessons from history. It can also promote the values enshrined in the EU Charter for Fundamental Rights, including freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination. This learning process is vital for fostering a fundamental rights culture in the EU. 	The Agency has created two toolkits in this area, one for teachers and another for public officials. It is also part of the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance to support EU Member States in implementing commitments set under the Stockholm Declaration. In addition, it is organising training for public officials on fundamental rights, citizenship, and learning from the Holocaust under the EU’s Slovak Presidency. They play a vital role in cultivating understanding among citizens, which is crucial in tackling antisemitism. It is not sufficient to remember and commemorate the past. The lessons from it must be applied now. Only then can we create a society for future generations grounded in mutual dignity, compassion and humanity, as opposed to hate.

title: FRA Director addresses Frontex Consultative Forum
text: He also highlighted the importance of setting up a pool of return monitors and an individual complaints mechanism as two new key human rights safeguards established in Frontex’s new regulation to increase fundamental rights accountability. The Forum met in Warsaw on 20 October. It was the first meeting following the entry into force of the new European Border and Coast Guard regulation, which has considerably expanded Frontex’s tasks. As a result Forum members reflected on the changing role of Frontex and what this means for the Forum. The 2016 priorities are: the fundamental rights implications of operationalising the Frontex amended Regulation; revision and further development of the Frontex Fundamental Rights Strategy and Action Plan; fundamental rights and Frontex-coordinated joint operations, with a specific focus on pre-identification and screening activities; and the development and evaluation of Frontex training tools and methodologies in areas related to Fundamental Rights.

title: Discussion on fundamental rights for cross-border justice
text: Participants from all EU Member States, the Council of Europe, as well as civil society organisations on EU criminal justice attended. The event aimed at hearing from the Member States how to best proceed in ensuring effective application of cross-border EU instruments relating to detention, in light of recent jurisprudence by the Court of Justice of the EU.

title: FRA and Committee of the Regions explore new cooperation activities
text: Suggestions included contributing to upcoming Committee of the Regions events or a joint publication. Continued regular exchange of information between the two organisations will also support each other’s work. The Committee of the Regions and the Agency already organise an Annual Dialogue every year to discuss fundamental rights themes of relevance at the regional and local level. It also allows knowledge of existing fundamental rights good practices to be shared. The 2016 Annual dialogue will take place in Brussels on 24 November and will address how local authorities can contribute to the fight against discrimination and intolerance that affects refugee children's right to education.

title: EU public communicators gather for EuroPCom 2016
text: The conference brings together communicators from European, national, regional and local authorities in the EU. Through dedicated sessions, various issues were addressed such as communicating to migrants, empowering citizens, online transparency or arts and culture. Learning from various projects, participants could exchange good practices and find inspiration for new activities to communicate about Europe. Lessons learned and ideas from the event will help shape the Agency’s activities in area of promoting and raising awareness of rights.

title: Access to justice legal handbook presented to national judges
text: It presented its Handbook on the European law relating to access to justice that was produced in collaboration with the European Court of Human Rights. The European Judicial Training Network is the principal platform and promoter for training and the exchange of knowledge of the European judiciary.

title: Trust in cross-border justice
text: The event, ‘Ensuring cross-border justice for all in the EU: sharing practices and experiences from the ground’, seeks to explore how to ensure there is fair, effective and accessible cross-border justice for everyone across the EU. Over 100 representatives from international and EU institutions, national governments, judges and other legal professionals, national human rights institutions and other ‘access to justice’ actors will be invited. They will exchange real-life practices and experiences in order to develop practical suggestions on how to strengthen cross-border justice. Participants will examine current trends and challenges in cross-border justice. They will focus on three particular areas and the related EU laws: common EU-wide rules to ensure fairness; mutual trust and mutual recognition among national legal practitioners; and better information and targeted guidance to improve rights awareness and access to justice. FRA will also use the event to launch two new reports and promote its access to justice handbook for legal practitioners which will be published in Slovak during the event, with more language versions to follow later. One report looks at right of suspected and accused people across the EU to translation, interpretation and information; the other looks at fundamental rights in pre- and post-trial cross-border transfer procedures in relation to criminal detention and their alternatives in the EU. Taken together, the event and reports aim to bring justice closer to everybody in the EU. They will enable decision makers to better understand and hence tackle the challenges in facilitating cross-border access to justice and national legal professionals to address the barriers in cross-border justice by drawing on existing promising practices.

title: Rights and border management discussed at Biometrics Institute’s Annual Conference
text: It drew on findings from its current project on biometrics in large-scale EU migration databases. The Agency’s intervention took place during a panel discussion on identification at borders. The conference brought together representatives of public authorities, industry, international organisation, academia, EU bodies and agencies, as well as NGOs.

title: Developing wellbeing indicators
text: The seminar was organised by the Social Situation Monitor. The wellbeing indicators are important tools for the European Commission’s efforts to monitor economic, social and territorial cohesion across the EU.

title: European Parliament discusses child protection best practices
text: The Agency took part in discussions. In addition to questions relating to the implementation of the child protection systems across the EU, challenges faced in the implementation of legislation and policies in Romania were discussed. The discussions underlined the need for strong cooperation between the authorities and civil society organisations, while maintaining high standards of training, supervision, vetting, accreditation, professional supervision and guidance, effective public inspection and monitoring. Participants also covered increased allocation of resources (both human and financial) to support effective and integrated child protection systems. This should take into account the especially difficult situation of various particular groups of children. These include those living in rural areas, children with disabilities, those belonging to ethnic minorities or living in conditions of extreme deprivation (particularly the Roma) and separated children who are irregular migrants.

title: 4 persistent migration challenges needing urgent action
text: Access the focus section on key issues after one year and the monthly data collection highlights. The report highlights these four priority areas after reviewing data collected over the past year. It signposts key areas that should be addressed to better safeguard the rights of asylum seekers and migrants. Some of the main findings include: Unaccompanied children – inadequate first child reception facilities often result in missing children. Qualified staff and clear guidance to identify children at risk are often lacking. Guardianship remains problematic with delays in appointment or the temporary use of reception staff hindering child protection and family reunification. In addition, children face legal and practical obstacles to access asylum procedures. They may also be detained to protect and prevent them from absconding. Violence and hate speech against migrants –hate crime and hate speech continues to be a major concern and seems to be worsening and spreading in some Member States. It spans physical attacks and murder, damage to property including arson, threats to aid workers and service providers, and hostile demonstrations against refugees. Such incidents are often politically-motivated and in part being carried out by vigilantes. There also have been incidents of police violence. Safety and protection at reception facilities – While they may have various protection and safety measures, incidents of abuse and sexual assault on women and children have been reported. This points to the need for specific measures to protect vulnerable people against violence that are often lacking. Impact on local communities – The lack of information and contact between local and refugee communities is contributing to growing hostility in many local communities. However, shifting budgets to the local level to deal with the impact of arrivals and integrating migrant children into local schools seems to be improving. Numerous challenges still remain to safeguard asylum seekers and migrants. This report underlines persistent issues from the past year that the EU and its Member States need to urgently address. The European Commission asked the Agency to collect data about the fundamental rights situation of people arriving in Member States, particularly affected by large migration movements. The countries covered are: Austria, Bulgaria, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy and Sweden. From next month, the Agency will extending reporting from Denmark, Finland, France, the Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia and Spain.
