Future reports will be shorter, including main findings for the Member States covered together with a thematic focus section. Specific findings for the Member States will include references to these for a better understanding of the challenges which affect several EU Member States or the EU as a whole. FRA has published overviews since September 2015. Each overview covers such issues as: initial registration and asylum applications; criminal proceedings initiated for offences related to irregular border crossings; child protection; reception conditions for new arrivals; access to healthcare; public response such as rallies of support, humanitarian assistance or voluntary work; racist incidents such as demonstrations, online hate speech or hate crime. Next month the focus will be on hate speech and hate crime.

title: International conference focuses on business and human rights
text: It was organised as part of the EU-funded FRAME Fostering Human Rights Among European Policies project. The conference was organised by the University of Seville, the Leuven Centre for Global Governance Studies at the University of Leuven, and the BHRight Initiative. The conference brought together scholars from various disciplines, together with international organisations such as the International Labour Organisation, business representatives and other experts. It sought to identify and examine issues that arise in the application and conceptualisation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and the ways to bridge the gap between global business and the protection of human rights. The Agency gave presentation focused on access to remedy at the EU level and its forthcoming opinion on business and human rights.

title: FRA local engagement for Roma inclusion work presented during visit to Greece
text: The meeting was hosted by the Greek Ministry of Interior and Administrative Reconstruction and focused on the empowerment and participation of Roma and Travellers in advisory and decision making bodies, as well as in political life; there was a specific focus on Roma women and youth. The Agency introducing its Local Engagement for Roma Inclusion (LERI) project and how it was implemented in Megara, Greece, one of the 21 participating localities. The presentation was of particular relevance, as it was given the day before the Greek Ministry of Interior organised a field visit to the Roma neighbourhood in Megara. The meeting brought together various stakeholders, including representatives of the Greek Ministries, local and regional authorities, local Roma NGOs and other civil society actors, as well as representatives from partner countries, international organisations and other CAHROM experts.

title: European Broadcasting Union meets FRA on the new Media Toolkit
text: The new toolkit will draw on the former 2008 Diversity Toolkit. It will be a ‘one-stop-shop’ of news examples, know-how tips and information sources for journalists covering news in which fundamental rights are at stake or questioned. The toolkit will be web-based, mobile friendly, and useful for community discussions in social media. The design will incite feedback from journalists, serving as a platform for further networking among media, and as an information source of latest research and findings. The Intercultural and Diversity Group discussed its role as co-producers, expressing its commitment in supporting the Agency in this project.

title: FRA presents Fundamental Rights Report 2016 in Finland
text: The Finnish Member of FRA’s Management Board and representatives of national authorities, civil society, legal practitioners, court officials and judges attended the event. The conference aimed at raising the visibility and awareness of the report in Finland, focusing particularly on the better and systematic use of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights nationally.

title: International conference focuses on rule of law
text: This expert body was created by the Council of Europe Committee of Ministers as an independent consultative body that issues opinions on a wide range of topics relating to constitutional law and human rights.

title: European Commission fundamental rights indicators training
text: Between 12 and 13 October, it hosted two colleagues from the Romanian country desk. The training focused on how to embed fundamental rights issues and apply fundamental rights-based indicators into the frameworks of the European Regional Development Fund programmes. In particular, the Agency supported the Directorate-General in reviewing the progress of regional development in Romania from a fundamental rights perspective and offered technical support in possible revisions of impact indicators for the mid-term review of the programme. The training focused on data collection and indicators covering Roma and people with disabilities. It drew on the Agency’s work in these areas as well as the experience of two study visitors from a Romanian project on mapping the Roma localities funded by the EEA grant and methodologically supported by FRA.

title: Expert meeting explores human rights education and fundamental rights awareness
text: The meeting took place from 9 to 11 October in Venice. It marked World Mental Health Day 2016 and was a follow up to one of the working groups at the Fundamental Rights Forum 2016. It was organised by the Agency, in cooperation with the European Federation of Psychologists Association and the European Inter-University Centre for Human Rights and Democratisation.

title: Disability working group looks at quality of services for people with disabilities
text: The meeting focused on quality and evaluation of services for people with disabilities, especially the role of workforces. On the second day, members of the working groups on disability, and ageing and care met jointly and discussed policies and practices related to people with disabilities growing older.

title: Joint Collaborative Platform on Social and Economic Rights meets
text: The platform brings together the Council of Europe, FRA, the European Network of National Human Rights Institutions (ENNHRI), and the European Network of Equality Bodies (EQUINET). The meeting discussed future perspectives and objectives for the platform and for social rights, including the new EU Pillar of Social Rights. There were also discussions on the design and use of indicators to monitor the effective enjoyment and respect of social rights and support Member States in this process.
